Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Imagining the Unimaginable: War, Weapons and Procurement Politics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project examines how nations make choices about the military weapons that they design and use. Previous research suggests that decisions about weapons technologies are driven mainly by security concerns or financial needs, but such factors cannot explain current patterns of weapons development across nations. This project will instead test the theory that the ways in which those involved in war and weapons development in each nation (i.e. military personnel, scientists, private firms, etc.) conceptualize future warfare shapes the kinds of weapons that they seek to design and procure. This theory will be tested in relation to the development and procurement of aircraft carriers, stealth technology, and autonomous weapons in the United States, United Kingdom, France, and India. Data for testing the theory will come from analyses of military documents in national archives, in-depth interviews with key figures in each nation, and a survey experiment designed to uncover how decisions are made regarding military budgets and weapons procurement.

This is a multi-method investigation of how and why nation states decide to create and procure different types of weapons technologies. It focuses on interactions among military personnel, politicians, scientists, private firms, and civil society organizations. The main contention is that these actors' conceptions of future warfare shape their choices about weapons procurement. Thus, each set of actors' identity, belief about the state of future conflict, and receptiveness to and interpretation of the laws and ethics of warfare shape the technical solutions that they will propose to different types of security threats. The extent to which these technological solutions are then transformed into weapons systems is predicted to be determined by the extent to which each set of actors has access to the decision-making process and the extent to which their ideas resonate with those of decision makers. The predicted result of interplay among these factors is that even when faced with similar threats, states end up making different choices regarding weapons procurement. This theory of weapons technology design and procurement will be tested by comparing archival, interview, and experimental data from the United States, United Kingdom, France, and India.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Countries around the world are increasingly investing in their military arsenals. This includes the development of the next generation of traditional military weaponry like aircraft carriers and fighter jets, the pursuit of cutting-edge technology such as missile defenses and drones, and the exploration of emerging fields of warfighting, including artificial intelligence and cyber security. Upon closely examining these developments, one can discern differences in the types of capabilities that countries adopt. For example, why did the United States invest in ever-more expansive forms of homeland missile defense, whereas France briefly dabbled in such matters and the United Kingdom has been reluctant to do so? And, why did India, despite the high cost, invest in its own missile defense capabilities? Hence, this project posits the following research question: Why and how do nations decide to procure certain weapon systems and what explains how they envision using them?

Existing explanations emphasize systemic threat, material interests, the availability of resources, or strategic culture. In contrast, this project argues that countries will pursue the development of particular weapon technologies based on whose ideas win out in the domestic political competition over ideas of the future of war. Indeed, domestic actors' ideas about future warfare, called the images of warfare, shape actors' preferences for particular military capabilities. Not all of these images of warfare are equally influential. This project therefore trace how those within the military, the legislative and executive branch, the industry, and the community of defense analysts bargain over such technological preferences. In order to transform ideas into actual capabilities, an actor need to build a cross-cutting coalition within the broader defense community around these imagined security interests, while exploiting formal or informal access points to the state.

To test this theory, this project has used comparative case studies, centered on the development of military capabilities around three major technologies in four different countries: air power (1920s-1930s), aircraft carriers (1950s-1960s), and missile defense (1990-today) in the United States, the United Kingdom, France, and India. For the historical cases, the researcher gathered original archival evidence, visiting eleven different archives and collecting about 65,000 relevant documents. She also conducted seventy-five semi-structured interviews with key defense stakeholders, including members of the armed services, foreign affairs officials, NATO officials, government representatives, politicians and their staff members, defense analysts, and members of civil society.

This dissertation made the following contributions to the study and practice of international security. This project shifted the focus away from explaining the mere possession of capabilities towards understanding why countries pursue particular types of military capabilities and how they intend to operate them. Inspired by Science and Technology Studies' conceptualization of technological development as a multidirectional and non-determined process that is shaped by social and political forces, this project presents a novel approach to studying and classifying countries' conventional weapon capabilities. Understanding these procurement choices allows us to grapple with defense spending, countries' actual conduct in armed conflict, and patterns in arms control and disarmament. Second, this work takes the role of ideas in military innovation seriously. More specifically, the researcher contends that ideas about the future matter for material outcomes. This dissertation thus brings together two, seemingly contrasting, variables: the agile nature of ideas on one hand and the material, expensive, non-fungible nature of weapon systems on the other hand. Third, this research advocates for a more dynamic understanding of the functioning of institutions. Rather than characterizing the relevant institutions as inherently beneficial for, or impeding, military innovation, the researcher argues that the openness of the institutions to these ideas will differ across countries and at various times within a country. Fourth, by having conducted extensive primary research, this project is able to contribute to the state of knowledge about each of the case studies.

The results of the study have been written up in the dissertation, which will be turned into a book manuscript once the dissertation has been defended. In addition, the researcher will submit a number of stand-alone articles on the basis of this research for review with high-ranking journals. Thus far, the research has been presented at various professional conferences and universities, including at the Harvard Kennedy School's Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs, Boston University, and Sciences Po. The research has also been shared with the broader public, for instance by making it publicly available through Brown's data repository and by presenting it in public fora, like the Future Strategy Forum.
